title: Restoring force - ball on a parabolic hill

content.question: A small ball is initially at rest at the top of a smooth curved hill. The hill’s surface is in the shape of a parabola. If the ball is rolled down the hill, is the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-component of its motion an example of simple harmonic motion? What reasoning supports the claim?

choices.label: Yes. The initial push on the ball displaces it from the equilibrium position.
Yes. The potential energy of the ball-Earth system is a quadratic function of position, resulting in a linear restoring force.
No. There is no equilibrium position for the ball.
No. The net force on the ball is in the same direction as the ball’s displacement from equilibrium.

content.answer: No. The net force on the ball is in the same direction as the ball’s displacement from equilibrium.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
